awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Integrative Makers Course and Laboratory for STEM Undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. To make STEM learning purposeful and fulfilling, this HBCU-UP TIP project aims to provide STEM juniors and seniors at Tuskegee University with experiences that are aligned with industry practices through a new and novel Makers Course and associated Makers Laboratory (MC&ML) called "Conducting Integrative STEM Research in a Makerspace". The MC&ML is designed to provide students with industry-like experiences needed STEM workforce readiness or graduate school preparation.  

The novelty of the MC&ML lies in its framework of the "Makerspace", a dedicated physical area where students from different STEM disciplines will convene for work on collaborative hands-on research projects in advanced multidisciplinary fields such as nanocomposites, biomaterials, smart materials, and computation modeling. The program interventions include: (1) the establishment of the MC&ML, (2) the use of "Learning through lectures and making" whereby teams of multidisciplinary faculty will lecture, mentor students and supervise projects on dedicated MSE-focused topics, (3) increased summer research internships opportunities, (4) Graduate Record Examination (GRE) preparation, and (5) Workshops for the Graduate Research Fellowship Programs and STEM-Related Workforce. As an HBCU, Tuskegee is a leader in educating and preparing minority students for STEM careers. The success of the MC&ML will contribute to increasing diversity in the STEM technology workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this HBCU-UP Targeted Infusion Program (TIP) program is to provide STEM juniors and seniors (from hereon referred to as “Scholars”) at Tuskegee University with experiences that are aligned with industry practices through a new and novel Makers Course and associated Makers Laboratory (MC&ML) called "Conducting Integrative STEM Research in a Makerspace". The novelty of the MC&ML lies in its framework of the "Makerspace", a dedicated physical area where students from different STEM disciplines convened for collaborative hands-on research projects in advanced multidisciplinary fields such as nanocomposites, biomaterials, smart materials, and computation modeling. The MC&ML is designed to provide students with industry-like experiences needed for STEM workforce readiness, making STEM learning purposeful and fulfilling. The HBCU-UP TIP program interventions consist of (1) The offering of the MC&ML; (2) The engagement of Scholars in learning STEM through "Learning through lectures and making" whereby teams of multidisciplinary faculty lecture, mentor these Scholars and supervise their projects on STEM-focused topics; (3) Presentations and workshops from invited industry personnel; and (4) Research experiences for Scholars in the MC&ML during summers.

The program has supported 73 Tuskegee University students (42 males, 31 females). Participants chosen for the program were primarily rising juniors and seniors from 9 STEM disciplines (Mechanical Engineering, Aerospace Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Chemistry, Physics, Biology, Agriculture, Mathematics). The program's multidisciplinary cutting-edge research, educational activities, and mentoring gave Scholars a challenging and meaningful experience. Moreover, all Scholars completed internships at National Labs, STEM industries, and NSF funded summer research experience programs. Additionally, 3 graduates of the program, have obtained Ph.D. degrees and 7 completed M.S. degrees, while 3 are currently pursuing Doctoral studies and 8 are enrolled in M.S. programs. Furthermore, an impressive 37 program graduates have joined the STEM workforce, while other Scholars are still completing their B.S. at Tuskegee University.

The Tuskegee University faculty and graduate student mentors, institutional leaders, staff members, alumni, and invited speakers provided unwavering support to the program resulting in the successful implementation of this HBCU-UP TIP program.

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2024
Modified by: Shaik Zainuddin
